section.name: Process
section.p: Open Participation Software is a new process, and we are trying to refine it as we go along. Please join the admin-dpml@lists.ibiblio.org mailing list if you want to partake in the discussion.

subsection.name: Repository Access
subsection.p: Once we have established a working contractual agreement between the people who are part of the community, we can enable the full vision of Open Participation Software, which includes the self-registration to get access to the source repository. The idea is that anyone who have spent enough time to work out a patch is committed enough to be a member (loose term) of the community. It is essentially no different than self registration to issue tracking systems. In fact, we have tied the Scarab registration to the Subversion access rights, so your username and password are always synchronized between these two fundamental systems.

We want to get tools in place to make it very easy to revert individual commits that are made either maliciously or unintentionally. It should only be a matter of running a commandline tool, which takes a revision number and undo that commit. This has not been done yet, and anyone with BASH, Perl or Python experience to do this are free to join in the fun and help out.

subsection.name: Coding Standard
subsection.p: We have a Coding Standard that we require everyone to follow. Remember that it is not difficult to write code, it is difficult to read it. So the Coding Standards are focussed on improving readability, sometimes at the expense that it takes more typing to do.

Checkstyle is used to validate the Coding Standard, and is very unforgiving. Since Checkstyle was introduced fairly late in our history, especially Metro has endless number of failures to comply. If you want to join in the fun and help out, it is a pretty good idea to start by helping fixing these Checkstyle reports. It gives you an idea of how the code is written, and you get comfortable with using the Subversion tool.
